He has affection for his entire ummah to obtain happiness in this world and the hereafter, like the affection of a father towards his children.

The Prophet's sons from Khadijah were three, namely Qasim, thayyib, and thahir, all of whom died before reaching puberty. From Mariyah al-Qibthiyah, the Prophet had a son named Ibrahim who also died when he was young. In addition to the three sons, the Prophet saw also had four daughters from Khadijah, namely Zainab, Ruqayyah, Ummu Kaltsum, and Fathimah. The first three died before the Prophet died.

Allah knows everything about who was appointed as the previous prophets and who was appointed as the final prophet. The following are hadiths that explain the position of the Prophet Muhammad as the final or last prophet, including:

From Jabir bin Muth'im that he said, "I heard the Messenger of Allah say, 'I have several names: I am Muhammad, I am Ahmad, I am al-Mahi by whom Allah erases disbelief, and I am al-hasyir under whose feet mankind will be gathered, and I am also al-'aqib after whom there will be no prophet.'" (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

From Jabir bin 'Abdullah that he said, "The Messenger of Allah said, 'My position among the prophets is like a man who built a house, he perfected and decorated it except for one place for a stone (brick that has not been installed). The person who enters the house and sees it says, 'How beautiful this house is, except for one place for a stone (brick that has not been installed), so I am the stone (brick that has not been installed), where I am the seal of prophethood.'" (Narrated by Muslim)

From Abu Hurairah that he said, "The Messenger of Allah said, 'I have been given preference over the prophets with six things: 1) I was given concise words that are comprehensive (in meaning). 2) I was helped with (given a sense of) fear (for the enemy). 3) Spoils of war were made lawful for me. 4) Allah made the earth pure (for *tayammum*) and a mosque for me. 5) I was sent to all of creation, and 6) I was made the seal of the prophets.'" (Narrated by Muslim and at-Tirmidzi)

From Anas bin Malik that he said, "The Messenger of Allah said, 'Apostleship and prophethood have been cut off, there will be no more apostles and prophets after me.'" (Narrated by Ahmad)
text.41:
In this verse, Allah encourages all believers who affirm Allah and His Messenger to engage in abundant remembrance (dhikr) of Allah by mentioning His name as much as possible, with both heart and tongue, in every circumstance and at all times. This is because Allah is the One who bestows upon them countless blessings. They are commanded to glorify Him (tasbih), meaning to cleanse and purify Allah from anything that is not befitting of Him.

This dhikr and tasbih are performed in the morning when one has just awakened from sleep, because at that time it is as if a person is brought back to life after death, to face a new life. Tasbih is also commanded in the evening because at that time a person has finished performing various tasks throughout the day. Dhikr at that time is a sign of gratitude to Allah for the abundance of His guidance (taufiq) and direction (hidayah) so that one can carry out their work well, and obtain sustenance for their needs and the livelihood of their family.

Through abundant dhikr, one can devote oneself to Allah and prepare for the afterlife. In addition, one can also examine the actions that have been carried out so that one can strive for the necessary improvements for the days to come.
text.42:
In this verse, Allah encourages all believers who affirm Allah and His Messenger to engage in abundant *dhikr*, remembering Allah by mentioning His name as much as possible with their hearts and tongues in every situation and at all times. This is because Allah is the One who bestows upon them countless blessings. They are commanded to glorify Him with *tasbih*, which means cleansing and sanctifying Allah from everything that is not befitting of Him.

This *dhikr* and *tasbih* are performed in the morning when one has just woken up from sleep, because at that time it is as if a person is brought back to life after death, to face a new life. It is also commanded to perform *tasbih* in the evening because at that time a person has finished doing various tasks throughout the day. *Dhikr* at that time is a sign of gratitude to Allah for the abundance of His *tawfiq* and *hidayah* so that one can carry out their work well, and obtain sustenance for their needs and the livelihood of their family.

With abundant *dhikr*, one can devote oneself to Allah and prepare for the afterlife. In addition, one can also examine the actions that have been carried out so that one can strive for the necessary improvements for the days to come.
text.43: Allah explains that He is the One who bestows mercy upon those who believe and tests them in the presence of the angels in the heavens. The angels then seek forgiveness for them so that Allah, with His *taufik*, *hidayah*, and mercy, brings them out from the darkness of disbelief into the light of faith. He is the Most Merciful to all Muslims in this world and the hereafter. In this world, Allah guides them to the right path, and in the hereafter, He grants them safety from great turmoil and calamity.
text.44:
When the believers enter the courtyards of Paradise, the angels greet them with the word "salam" as in Allah's saying:

And the angels will enter upon them from every gate, [saying], "Peace be upon you for what you patiently endured. And excellent is the final home." (ar-Ra'd/13: 23-24)

Allah provides rewards for them in the Hereafter that come without being requested beforehand. They experience the pleasure of delicious food, drinks, clothing, and dwellings in the vast expanse of Paradise. The delights of Paradise have never been seen by the eye, heard by the ear, or even conceived in the heart.
text.45:
In this verse, Allah explains to Prophet Muhammad that he was sent to be a witness over the people (ummah) who had previously received His message. Allah sent him as a bearer of good news to those who affirmed his message and practiced the guidance he brought, that they would be admitted into Paradise. He was also a warner to those who denied his message, that they would be punished with the torment of Hellfire.

Regarding the Prophet's function as a witness (syahid), Allah states in another verse:

And how will it be when We bring from every nation a witness and We bring you, [O Muhammad], against these [people]? (an-Nisa'/4: 41)
text.46: The Prophet also played the role of a preacher of Allah's religion to all of mankind so that they would acknowledge His oneness and all His attributes of perfection. It also aimed to make people worship Allah with sincerity; to provide enlightenment like a bright lamp that can bring them out of the darkness of disbelief into the light of faith, and illuminate the path that will be taken by believers so that they may be happy in this world and the hereafter. All of the Prophet saw's duties were carried out with the permission and command of Allah.
text.47:
Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari and 'Ikrimah have narrated a hadith from al-Hasan explaining that when the verse al-Fath/48:2 was revealed:

"That Allah may forgive you (O Muhammad) your sins of the past and the future." (al-Fath/48:2)

The companions asked, "O Messenger of Allah! We have known what Allah has done for you, so what will Allah do for us?" Then this verse (al-Ahzab/33:47) was revealed.

In this verse, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad to convey glad tidings to the believers that indeed Allah has prepared for them a great bounty that exceeds the bounty given to other communities, because they were given the ability to improve the morals of society from various injustices to justice and benefit. They were also able to change the face of the communities they faced from an attitude of defiance to an attitude of submission and obedience for the improvement of their fate in this world and in the Hereafter.
text.48: In this verse, Allah explains what can cause harm. Allah forbids believers from obeying the disbelievers and the hypocrites. They are also commanded not to heed the disturbances of the disbelievers towards the continuation of the da'wah (call) to the path of Allah, and to face them with patience and reliance (tawakal). Allah is the One who should be regarded as the protector in carrying out the task of da'wah for the flourishing of the symbols of Islam.
text.49:
In this verse, Allah explains that if a divorce occurs between a believer and his wife who has not yet been consummated, then the divorced woman has no 'iddah (waiting period), and she can immediately remarry another man. The former husband who divorced her should give mut'ah, which is a gift to comfort and please the heart of the divorced wife. The size of the mut'ah depends on the husband's ability, according to Allah's word:

"There is no blame upon you if you divorce women you have not touched [i.e., had sexual relations with] nor specified for them an obligation. But give them [a gift of] compensation - upon the wealthy according to his means and upon the poor according to his means - a provision according to what is acceptable, a duty upon the doers of good." (al-Baqarah/2: 236)

It should be noted that if the woman has to leave the house, then the way to remove her should be with politeness so as not to cause her heartache. She must be given reasonable provisions, so that the gift is truly a consolation that alleviates the suffering of her heart due to the divorce she experienced. It is narrated from Sahl bin Sa'ad and Abu Usaid:

The Prophet (saw) married Umaimah bint Syarahil. When Umaimah entered the house (of the Prophet), the Prophet extended his hand to her, but she seemed to dislike (the Prophet's way of welcoming her). So the Prophet ordered Abu Usaid to give her two good pieces of clothing that were well-known at that time (as a divorce gift). (Riwayat al-Bukhari)
text.50:
In this verse, Allah has clearly made it lawful for Prophet Muhammad to have relations with the women he married and gave dowries to. Also made lawful for him were slave girls (*jariyah*) obtained in warfare, such as Safiyyah bint Huyai bin Akhtab, who was obtained during the Battle of Khaybar. The Prophet (saw) freed Safiyyah, and that freedom became her dowry. The same was true of Juwairiyah bint al-Harith from Bani Mushthaliq, who was freed and married by the Prophet (saw). As for the slave girls (*jariyah*) who were gifted to the Prophet, they were Raihanah bint Sham'un and Mariyah al-Qibthiyah, who gave birth to the Prophet's son, Ibrahim.

Allah also made it lawful for the Prophet to marry the daughters of his paternal brothers and the daughters of his paternal sisters, the daughters of his maternal brothers, the daughters of his maternal sisters who emigrated with the Messenger of Allah, and a believing woman who offers herself to the Prophet (saw) if the Prophet wishes to marry her.

These concessions are only specific to the Prophet and not for all believers, with the understanding that if a woman offers herself to be married by a Muslim, even voluntarily, it is still obligatory to pay her dowry. It is different if the woman offers herself to be married by the Prophet (saw), then she may be married without a dowry.

If the form (value) of the dowry is not mentioned when the marriage contract is concluded, then its form can be determined by *mahar mitsl*, which is a dowry whose value is the same as the value of the dowry usually given to her family. The stipulation to pay *mahar mitsl* is after intercourse has occurred between the two or after the husband has died but has not had intercourse. If a divorce occurs between husband and wife before intercourse, then what must be paid is half of the dowry that has been determined, and he can be exempted from paying the dowry if his wife is willing to relinquish it.

Allah knows what He has obligated to the believers regarding their wives and the slave girls they possess, such as the conditions of the marriage contract and others, and it is not permissible to marry a woman by way of gift or without witnesses. Regarding slave girls who are bought or not bought, they must be slave girls who are lawful for their owners to have relations with, such as slave girls who are People of the Book, not slave girls who are polytheists or of the Majusi religion. Allah is Most Forgiving, Most Merciful to His believing servants if they repent from the sins they committed before they received guidance.
text.51:
In this verse, Allah grants the Prophet Muhammad the freedom to postpone (defer conjugal relations with) whichever of his wives he wills, and to cohabit with whichever of them he wills. He is also given the freedom to remarry his divorced wives, considering the benefit for himself and the community.

It is narrated by Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari from Abu Razin that when the verse was revealed instructing the wives of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) to choose between remaining the Prophet's wives in a state of simplicity without luxury, or separating from the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) in pursuit of worldly pleasures more suited to their desires, the wives of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) became apprehensive. They unanimously declared their willingness to remain with the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) in any condition, because they prioritized the religious aspect of life over worldly pleasures.

Then the Prophet postponed conjugal relations with some of his wives at their request, such as Umm Habibah, Maimunah, Saudah, Safiyyah, and Juwairiyah. For these five wives, the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) did not arrange a regular rotation for overnight stays. As for his other four wives, namely 'Aishah, Hafsah, Zainab, and Umm Salamah, he arranged a rotation for overnight stays and equalized the distribution of clothing and food.

The Prophet's freedom to arrange the rotation, food, clothing, and other things was in accordance with the Prophet's just nature in implementing Allah's guidance, so as not to cause jealousy in the hearts of his wives. They willingly accepted the Prophet's treatment.

It is narrated from 'Abdullah bin Yazid that 'Aishah once said, "It was the habit of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) to divide the turns fairly among his wives, then the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) would pray, "O Allah, this is my division concerning what I control (i.e., the distribution of material things), so do not blame me for what You control and I do not control (i.e., love)." (Narrated by Ahmad)

This hadith contains an encouragement to maintain the purity of the heart and a threat to those who do not submit to the decrees of Allah and His Messenger. Allah is All-Knowing of all the secrets hidden in the heart, and Most Forbearing, always giving an opportunity to repent to those who have realized their error and want to return to the straight path.
text.52:
Allah did not permit the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) to marry other women after this verse was revealed. Allah also forbade him from replacing them with other wives, even if their beauty attracted the Prophet's attention, except for female slaves obtained from warfare or those gifted to him.

Abu Dawud and al-Baihaqi narrated from Anas bin Malik that he said, "After Allah commanded the wives of the Prophet to choose, and they chose to remain under the Prophet's household, Allah Ta'ala then restricted the Prophet from adding to his nine wives by not marrying again." And Allah is Ever Watchful over all things.

Allah permitted Prophet Muhammad to have more than four wives containing a very high wisdom because the marriage was determined by Allah, the All-Knowing and All-Wise. Among the wisdoms are:

1.  Conveying specific laws for women that are not known except by husband and wife. If there are many wives, then many laws about women can be obtained. The acceptance or rejection of narrations originating from them is greatly influenced by the number of narrations.

2.  The need for strong supporters for the da'wah (propagation) at the beginning of Islam. Relationships through in-laws and marriage traditionally support and help each other.

3.  Every Muslim certainly wants to establish family ties with the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), so that they can freely enter the Prophet's house. In fact, every Muslim wants to be able to serve the Prophet.

4.  The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) repaid the services of those who defended him in the struggle of Islam. A very valuable reward was becoming in-laws and marrying their families, such as the Prophet's marriage to 'Aisha bint Abu Bakr and Hafsah bint 'Umar.

5.  Abolishing the traditions of ignorance (jahiliyyah) with more beneficial laws, such as his marriage to Zainab. Actually, the Prophet did not want it because he feared the reproach of people, but this was useful for maintaining lineage and kinship.

6.  The Prophet was able to act justly and provide guidance to his family, which others did not possess.
text.53:
In this verse, Allah teaches manners or etiquette regarding the household of the Prophet Muhammad (saw). Allah forbids believers from entering the houses of the Prophet (saw) except with his permission, to eat in his house without waiting for the food to be cooked. During the time of the Messenger of Allah, there were people who waited for meal times. Then this verse was revealed, prohibiting such actions. If the Messenger of Allah invited some companions to his house to attend a walimah, they were forbidden from entering the Prophet's house (saw) unless they already knew that the food was ready to be served.

If the food was not ready and they were still busy preparing it, the entry of guests would disturb the peace of the Prophet's family (saw). This would also disturb the Prophet's wives (saw) who were working, as some parts of their bodies that should not be seen by the guests would be exposed. They are allowed to enter if they have been invited. When they have finished eating, they should leave immediately without prolonging the conversation, because it really disturbs the Prophet (saw), and he himself feels shy to tell his guests to leave. However, Allah is not ashamed to explain the truth.

Allah teaches politeness in the household so that it is observed by all guests who visit people's homes. If there is a need to ask for or borrow something from the wives of the Prophet (saw), then the request should be made from behind a screen and not directly face-to-face. Such a thing is more purifying for the hearts of both parties and does not hurt the heart of the Messenger of Allah. Included in the actions that hurt the heart of the Messenger of Allah is marrying his wives after he dies. The prohibition against marrying the former wives of the Prophet (saw) is a prohibition that applies forever because the act is a very great sin in the sight of Allah.

The Prophet is more worthy of the believers than themselves, and his wives are their mothers. (al-Ahzab/33: 6).

Imam al-Bukhari narrated from Anas that Umar bin Khaththab once said, "There were three of my opinions that were in accordance with the revelation sent down by Allah. First, I said to the Messenger of Allah, 'O Messenger of Allah, how good it would be if you made the maqam Ibrahim a place of prayer,' then Allah revealed the verse:

And take the maqam Ibrahim as a place of prayer. (al-Baqarah/2: 125)

Second, I said, 'O Messenger of Allah, indeed your wives are often visited by good and bad people, if you made a screen for them it would certainly be better,' then Allah revealed this verse of hijab. Third, I once said to the wives of the Prophet when they disagreed because of jealousy towards the Prophet, then this verse was revealed:

If he (the Prophet) divorces you, perhaps his Lord will give him in exchange wives better than you. (at-Tahrim/66: 5)
text.54: The reason for the revelation of this verse, as narrated by Juwaibir from Ibn 'Abbas, is that a man came to some of the wives of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) who was his cousin's son, and spoke directly with the Prophet's wife. The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) reprimanded him for this, saying, "Do not do this again on another occasion." The man replied, "O Messenger of Allah, this is my cousin's daughter, and I have never said anything evil, nor should the woman say anything bad to me." The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "We know that. There is none more jealous than Allah, and there is no one more jealous than me." Then the man left, saying, "Who can prevent me from talking to my cousin's daughter; I will surely marry her after Muhammad dies." Then this verse of hijab was revealed, and the man regretted the words he had uttered. To cover his mistake and atone for his sin, he offered expiation by freeing a slave, providing supplies for jihad with ten camels, and performing Hajj on foot.
text.55:
There is no sin upon the wives of the Prophet to meet without a veil with their fathers, whether biological or foster fathers, their sons, whether descendants or foster sons, their brothers, or the sons of their brothers, both male and female, Muslim women, near or far, or the slaves they own, both male and female. The existence of a hijab between them would cause many difficulties because they are always serving in household matters. But, what needs to be remembered is to always be mindful of Allah, to follow His commands and avoid His prohibitions, because Allah always witnesses everything they do.

The people mentioned in this verse, namely the fathers of the Prophet's wives, their sons, their brothers, their nephews or sons of their siblings, whether brothers or sisters, or other women and also their slaves are *mahram*, that is, people who are not allowed to marry them.

As for people other than those mentioned above, namely those who are not *mahram*, they are not allowed to meet the wives of the Prophet without a *hijab*. This is to protect the honor of the Prophet's wives, who are *ummahatul mu'minin* (mothers of the believers).
text.56:
Indeed, Allah bestows His mercy upon the Prophet Muhammad, and the angels seek forgiveness for him. Therefore, Allah encourages all Muslims to also send blessings (salawat) upon the Prophet (peace be upon him) and to greet him with full respect.

It is narrated from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri that he asked, "O Messenger of Allah, as for giving you greetings of peace, we already know it, how should we recite the salawat?" The Prophet replied, say: Allahumma shalli 'ala Muhammad wa 'ala ali Muhammad kama shallaita 'ala Ibrahim wa 'ala ali Ibrahim innaka hamid majid. Allahumma barik 'ala Muhammad wa 'ala ali Muhammad kama barakta 'ala Ibrahim wa 'ala ali Ibrahim innaka hamid majid. (Narrated by al-Bukhari, Ahmad, an-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, and others)

It is also narrated by 'Abdullah bin Abu thalhah from his father:

That the Messenger of Allah came one day and signs of joy were visible on his face. Then we asked, "We have seen signs of joy on your face." The Prophet replied, "Indeed, Jibril has come to me and said, 'O Muhammad, indeed your Lord has conveyed greetings of peace to you and said, 'Are you not pleased that there is no one from your ummah who sends blessings (salawat) upon you except that I will reward him with ten times as much. And there is no one who conveys greetings of peace to you from your ummah except that I will return the greeting of peace ten times as much."
text.57:
This verse explains that Allah curses those who harm Him by committing deeds that displease Him, such as denying His commands, like the Christians' statement that Jesus is the son of God, or like the polytheists who say that angels are the daughters of Allah, or associating partners with Him. Allah also curses those who harm His Messenger, such as accusing him of being a poet, a sorcerer, or a madman, and so on.

Allah's curse encompasses curses in this world and the Hereafter. In this world, they are distanced from Allah's mercy and grace, so they wallow in misguidance and disobedience. In the Hereafter, they are plunged into the fire of Hell, which is the worst of all places to return to, and Allah has prepared for them a very painful and humiliating punishment.
text.58:
Those who harm believing men and women without any offense they committed, and only based on slander and fabricated accusations, then indeed they have committed a manifest sin. According to Ibn 'Abbas, this verse was revealed in connection with the accusation of 'Abdullah bin Ubay against 'Aisha, who he said had committed indecency on the return journey with the Prophet Muhammad after fighting the Bani Mushthaliq, which is known as the hadith al-ifk.

In a hadith of the Prophet (saw) it is explained:

Abu Hurairah narrated that the Messenger of Allah was once asked about what is meant by backbiting. He replied, "You mention your brother with something he dislikes." The Prophet was asked again, "What if what is mentioned is true or a reality?" The Prophet replied, "If what is said is true, you have backbitten him, and if it is not true, then you have fabricated a lie against him." (Narrated by Abu Dawud)
text.59: Allah commands all Muslim women, especially the wives of the Prophet and his daughters, to draw their jilbabs over their entire bodies. This is so that they may be easily recognized by their clothing, as distinct from *jariyah* (female slaves), so that they are not harassed by those who abuse opportunities. A woman who dresses modestly is more likely to avoid harassment from ignorant people. While a woman who exposes her *aurat* in public is easily accused or judged as a woman of poor character. For those who in the past were less careful in covering their *aurat*, and then make amends, then Allah is Most Forgiving, Most Merciful. Because harmful acts are often committed by hypocrites, in the following verse Allah threatens them with a very severe threat.
text.60:
If the hypocrites, those with sickness in their hearts, and those who spread false news in Medina do not cease from denying Allah, harming His Messenger, and the believers, then Allah will surely command His Prophet to fight them so that they will no longer be able to live longer in Medina as neighbors to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Those who are threatened with being fought and destroyed by the Prophet are three groups of people:

1.  The hypocrites who always oppose Allah in secret.

2.  Those with sickness in their hearts, such as envy and resentment, who always harm the believers, such as harassing women.

3.  Those who spread false news in Medina, thereby harming the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), with their statements that the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would be defeated and expelled from Medina, and so on.
text.61: Those three groups are cursed wherever they are, because of their attitude that is always hostile and detrimental to religion and state, they are always pursued to be captured and killed. The fate of such people has also been experienced by those before them because that is the sunnah of Allah.
text.62: Thus, the sunnah of Allah that has been in effect upon those who came before the sending of the Prophet Muhammad saw will also be in effect for generations that come after. That is impossible to change and will certainly be in effect.
text.63: Many people asked the Prophet Muhammad about when the Day of Judgment would come. The polytheists asked about the Day of Judgment mockingly and scornfully, challenging that the Day of Judgment be brought about immediately. The hypocrites asked about the Day of Judgment driven by the assumption that the Prophet saw would answer as they predicted. As for the Jews, they asked with the intention of testing the truthfulness of the Prophet saw, whether his answer would be the same or not as what is contained in the Torah, that the matter of the Day of Judgment is truly in the hands of Allah.
text.64:
Then Allah explains that only He knows when the Day of Judgment will occur. It is possible that the time of the Day of Judgment is near, because everything that is to come is indeed always approaching and may be near. An Arabic proverb says:

"Every thing that is coming is near."

Then Allah will curse and distance the disbelievers from His goodness and mercy. Allah has also prepared for them the Sa'ir Fire.
text.65: They will abide in Hell forever, and will not find any protector to shield them from Allah's punishment. Nor will they find any helper to save them from His torment.
text.66: They will not find any protector or helper when they are turned over and over in the Fire. Filled with regret, they will say, "How fortunate we would have been if we had obeyed Allah and obeyed Muhammad, His Messenger."
text.67: They said with a feeling of resentment because they were deceived by their leaders and dignitaries in the world, "Our Lord, indeed we in the world followed our leaders and dignitaries, and they led us astray from the right path."
text.68:
Those who harbor resentment towards those who have led them astray will say, "Our Lord, give them double the punishment, first because they were misguided, and secondly because they misled others, and curse them with a great curse." Their complaint is reinforced by another verse, such as in Allah's statement:

And (remember) the Day when the wrongdoer will bite his hands and say, "Oh, would that I had taken with the Messenger [a] way. Oh, woe to me! I wish I had not taken that one as a friend. He almost led me away from the remembrance (the Qur'an) after it had come to me. And ever is Satan, to man, a deserter." (al-Furqan/25: 27-29)
text.69:
Allah forbids the believers from behaving like a group of the Children of Israel who harmed the Prophet Musa. Allah cleared him of the accusations they hurled at him. He was a person who had a very honorable position in the sight of Allah. This verse does not mention how they harmed the Prophet Musa.

In a narration about the death of Harun, as narrated by Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari from Ibn 'Abbas from 'Ali bin Abi Talib, he said, "When the Prophet Musa and Harun ascended the mountain, the Prophet Harun then died. The Children of Israel then became angry with the Prophet Musa, 'You have killed Harun, even though he was more beloved to us than you.'"

In a hadith, the Messenger of Allah said:

Narrated from Ibn Mas'ud that the Messenger of Allah (saw) one day distributed spoils of war to his companions, then a man from the Ansar said that the distribution was not intended to obtain the pleasure of Allah. Hearing this statement, the Prophet (saw) was offended until his face turned red, saying, "May Allah have mercy on Musa who was harmed by people more than this, but he remained patient." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)
text.70: In this verse, Allah commands the believers to remain pious to Him. Allah also commands the believers to always speak the truth, in harmony between what is intended and what is spoken, because every word spoken is recorded by the angels Raqib and 'Atid, and must be accounted for before Allah. Allah says:
text.71: If they consistently maintain their faith and piety and always speak the truth, surely Allah will improve their deeds and forgive their sins. Whoever desires happiness in this world and the hereafter, then there is only one path to take, which is to obey Allah and His Messenger. By doing so, they will obtain a great happiness in this world and the hereafter.
text.72:
Indeed, Allah offered religious duties to the heavens, the earth, and the mountains. Because the three did not have the preparation to receive that heavy trust (amanat), they all refused to bear the trust that Allah offered.

Then, the trust to carry out religious duties was offered to humans, and they accepted it with the consequence that whoever carries it out will be rewarded and admitted into Paradise. Conversely, whoever betrays it will be punished and cast into the fire of Hell. Although their physical form is smaller compared to the other three creatures (the heavens, the earth, and the mountains), humans dared to accept the trust because humans possess potential. However, because within humans there exists ambition and desires (syahwat) that often deceive the eyes and close the vision of their hearts, Allah describes them as very unjust (zalim) and ignorant because they did not sufficiently consider the consequences of accepting that trust (amanat).
text.73: Allah then explains that the consequence of accepting this trust (amanat) is that He will punish the hypocrites (munafik) and the polytheists (musyrik), both men and women, if they neglect the implementation of the trust they have undertaken. Allah will accept the repentance of the believing men and women who obediently carry out that trust. Indeed, Allah is Oft-Forgiving, Most Merciful.
